title: Japanese views of Christianity
prayerSummary: Give thanks that many Christians are respected, and pray for open hearts toward Christ through them.
Pray that negative stereotypes or false ideas about Christianity will be changed through positive interactions with Christians.
Pray that Christians and churches would be welcoming and share the gospel in ways that are easy to understand.
textBody: When Masako, a Japanese non-Christian lady, visited a church, she asked a church member about the meaning of a verse in a hymn. No one, not even the Bible school student, knew. The pastor only knew because he’d studied classical Japanese.

Due to experiences like Masako’s, some Japanese people have an impression that Christianity is difficult to understand or is old-fashioned. Stereotypes can remain despite churches using modern Bible translations and songs. Other people may not know enough to have any opinion at all.
Further misunderstandings can emerge through contacts with Jehovah's Witnesses or cults that seem Christian. Without knowing the differences, people can turn away from seeking Jesus altogether.
Some people are deterred by the idea that Christianity is “Western” or foreign, although this aspect can attract others.

There are positive impressions too. Some Japanese people see Christians as caring or kind, involved with helping the poor or disadvantaged. Others see the Bible as a source of wisdom, or consult Christians whom they respect for advice. Despite being a tiny percentage of the population, many Christians have had a positive influence on society. Over the decades, they’ve started medical and educational institutions and, in recent years, responded to disasters.

photos.title: A university chapel in Tokyo. It's not uncommon for churches to have a traditional Western layout and solemn atmosphere. While some appreciate this, others might find it too formal or somber.
A pulpit at a historical church in Yokohama. People may have an image of Christian preaching or sermons as being serious or strict.
A Japanese Bible and hymnal. The heftiness of the Bible may seem overwhelming to new Christians and even to some who are more mature.

A statue of Francis Xavier, the first known missionary to Japan. He was a Portuguese Jesuit missionary who arrived in Kagoshima in 1549. Japanese students learn about Xavier in school, and so, may have some knowledge about the beginnings of Christianity in Japan.

A statue of Shiro Amakusa, the teenage Christian leader of the Shimabara rebellion in 1637. This rebellion is described as an uprising of Christian peasants who opposed the shogunate's extreme tax policies and prohibitions against Christianity. Their defeat led to stricter prohibitions against Christianity and to over 200 years of national isolation starting in 1639.

A close-up of the Twenty-Six Martyrs Monument in Nagasaki. This monument memorializes 20 Japanese believers and 6 foreign Catholic priests who were marched over 800 kilometers from Kyoto to Nagasaki to be crucified.
The Twenty-Six Martyrs Monument in Nagasaki. There are many other sites in Nagasaki and throughout Kyushu related to the suffering of early Christians in Japan.

Stories of the early Jesuit priests and Christians were further popularized through Shusaku Endo's historical fiction novel, Silence. Endo was a prolific writer in Japan, and Silence was most recently adapted into a movie by Martin Scorsese in 2016.

A memorial in Yokohama to James Hepburn, an influential Protestant missionary in the mid 1800s. Hepburn was also a physician who created the first Japanese-English dictionary, popularized the romaji alphabet, was part of the translation team for the Japanese Bible, and helped to start churches and schools.

Protestant missionaries in the 1800s were known for their societal contributions including schools like this one, Aoyama Gakuin University in Tokyo. Aoyama Gakuin was originally founded in 1874 by Methodist Episcopalian missionaries.
Protestant missionaries in the 1800s were also known for starting hospitals. St. Luke's International Hospital in Tokyo was founded by American Episcopalian missionaries in 1901.

A missionary involved in ministry to the homeless community. Today, Christians continue to known for their acts of service and kindness in the community and seek to show the love of Christ through both word and deed. Photo by Alex Hyou. Used with permission.
Volunteers from a Christian disaster relief network helping with cleanup from the 2024 Noto peninsula earthquake in Ishikawa. Photo used with permission from Noto Help.
Many people have positive impressions of missionaries in Japan as being friendly, outgoing, and easy to confide in.

Gospel choirs became popular in the early 1990s through the Sister Act movies. There are choirs across Japan that sing Christian gospel songs in English, but most people who participate in them are not Christian.
A gospel choir that meets in a local church in Tokyo. The woman who leads the choir is a Christian, but most of the people in the choir are not.
A famous novel called Shiokari Pass based on the true story of a Christian railway employee. This book was written by Ayako Miura, a prolific Japanese writer known for her Christian faith.
The location of the actual Shiokari train station in Hokkaido that is featured in Ayako Miura's novel Shiokari Pass.

A local church group singing Christmas carols near a train station. Christmas is the main holiday associated with Christianity in Japan. Many Japanese people are more open to attending a church event or service during this time.

Christmas in Japan is most commonly celebrated with friends or a romantic partner. Common elements include illuminated streets and trees, images of Santa Claus, and eating Kentucky Fried Chicken and strawberry shortcake.
A manga series featuring Jesus and Buddha as roommates living together in Tokyo. It has been an ongoing monthly serial since 2006.
A shop window displaying wedding dresses. "Christian" weddings are popular in Japan. By this, people usually mean a Western style ceremony with the bride in a white wedding dress.

Some buildings that look like churches or cathedrals are actually commercial wedding venues that offer "Christian" weddings officiated by a Caucasian person in the role of a minister. Neither the bride or groom, nor even the officiant, need to have Christian faith.
